Engineering titanium oxide-based support for electrocatalysis Ke Chen 1 Tao Shen 1 Yun Lu Yezhou Hu Jingyu Wang Jian Zhang Deli Wang ⁎ Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry for Energy Conversion and Storage (Huazhong University of Science and Technology), Ministry of Education, Hubei Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry and Service Failure, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430074, Hubei, China Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry for Energy Conversion and Storage (Huazhong University of Science and Technology) Ministry of Education Hubei Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry and Service Failure School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Huazhong University of Science and Technology Wuhan 430074 Hubei China Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry for Energy Conversion and Storage (Huazhong University of Science and Technology), Ministry of Education, Hubei Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry and Service Failure, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430074, Hubei, China ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally. Graphical abstract Recent progresses in engineering the TiOx-based supports by shaping, doping, preparing titanium suboxide and TiO2-carbon composite are summarized for designing highly efficient electrocatalysts. The corrosion and weaker interaction with metal catalysts of common carbon supports during electrocatalysis push the development of alternative supports materials. Titanium oxide-based materials have been widely explored as electrocatalysts supports in consideration of their chemical stability, strong interactions with metal catalyst and wider applications in electrocatalytic reactions as well as the improved electronic conductivity. This review summarizes recent research advances in engineering titanium oxide-based supports for the catalysts in electrocatalysis field to provide guidance for designing high performance non-carbon supported electrocatalysts. Typically, the titanium oxide-based supports are classified into shaped TiO2, doped TiO2, titanium suboxide and TiO2-carbon composites according to the modification methods and corresponding preparation methods. Then the engineering strategies and electrocatalytic applications are discussed in detail. Finally, the challenges, future research directions and perspectives of titanium oxide-based supports for electrocatalysis are presented for practical applications. Keywords Titanium oxide support Electrocatalysis Strong metal-support interaction Electrochemical reactions 1 Introduction Metal catalysts are essential for electrochemical energy-related systems such as fuel cells and water splitting devices [1]. The fuel cell related reactions mainly consist of anodic hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR), methanol/ethanol/formic acid oxidation (MOR/EOR/FAOR) reaction and cathodic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). The water splitting involves the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [2]. The mechanical investigations show that the binding strength of intermediates adsorbed on metal surface during electrocatalysis should neither strong nor weak, which requires a modest adsorption energy [3,4]. The d-band center has been selected as the descriptor of adsorption property of metals, which could be tuned by several strategies including the metal-support interaction [5,6]. Besides, supports served as a promoter especially in anodic oxidation reaction for facilitating removal of poisoning species like adsorbed CO intermediate and promoting HER through H spillover effect [7–9]. So selecting rational metal catalysts and support material is crucial for promoting the energy conversion efficiency by decreasing overpotential. To achieve promising performance in catalysis, supports should simultaneously possess the merits of good stability in operating conditions, large specific area with reasonable morphology, strong interaction with the catalyst, low cost and superior conductivity [10]. Carbon materials are widely selected as the support for metal electrocatalysts, due to their high conductivity and large specific surface area. However, these carbon-supported catalysts may suffer from performance degradation after long-term operation, probably due to the support corrosion or catalyst particles ripening and aggregation [11–18]. Especially, in proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) systems, carbon support tends to suffer severe corrosion during start-up/shut-down operation following reaction (1). (1) C + 2H 2 O → CO 2 + 4H + + 4e - In the fuel starved regions, the potential tends to elevate to a high value where the carbon oxidation or electrolyte oxidation occurs [19]. As a result, catalytic performance can easily fade due to the possible detachment or aggregation of the catalyst particles. Hence, developing stable and corrosion-resistant catalysts supports is urgent for any catalytic systems [20,21]. Besides carbon-based support, metal oxide supports have aroused tremendous attention as alternative supports in electrochemical reaction systems [22]. Table S1 lists the applications of tin oxide, cerium oxide and tungsten oxide-based supports. Tin oxide-based supports are mainly employed to promote the OER, ORR and MOR/EOR performance. Cerium oxide-based materials have been selected as the catalysts supports in catalyzing (Nitrogen reduction reaction) NRR, FAOR, HER and MOR/EOR. Tungsten oxide supports have also shown promoting effect in HER, OER and alcohol oxidation reactions. Compared with above mentioned metal oxide supports, titanium oxide-based supports exhibit wider applications in both the anodic and cathodic reactions which are summarized in the following sections. Typically, TiO2 has been widely applied in photocatalytic systems as an n-type semiconductor with a wide band gap at about 3.0 eV and 3.2 eV for rutile and anataze phase respectively [23–29]. For multiple TiO2 crystal phase, the anatase and rutile phase are the most investigated phase compared with brookite phase, and rutile phase is the most stable among these TiO2 phases [30–34]. The anatase TiO2 is stable under low temperatures and begins to transform into rutile phase above 600 °C, accompanied by the increased crystalline size [35]. To stabilize the anatase TiO2 at a higher temperature, doping with the cations has been proved to be effective [36]. Titanium suboxides (Ti x O2 x - 1, 4 ≤ x ≤ 10) with oxygen vacancies also drew much attention to researchers in the catalyst support field [37–39], which were firstly put forward by Magnéli A. in 1950s [40], also known as Magnéli phase titanium oxides, different from the aforementioned TiO2 with oxygen vacancies. They are often produced by reduction of the TiO2 at high temperature up to 1,000 °C, forming partial Ti3+ and oxygen vacancies [39,41], which enhance the electronic conductivity of TiO2. Walsh and Wills [40] found that the electronic conductivity of Ti x O2 x -1 varies with the value of x. When x = 4 or 5, the Ti x O2 x -1 shows great electronic conductivity. To enhance the electronic conductivity of stoichiometric TiO2, doping by heteroatoms, introducing oxygen vacancies and forming composites with conductive carbon have been confirmed to be effective due to the decrease band gap as shown in Fig. S1. The electronic conductivity could be optimized to the value of metal-like property. In recent years, great efforts have been devoted to supporting nanocatalysts on titanium oxide-based materials for different electrocatalytic reactions such as oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [42,43] and methanol oxidation reaction (MOR) [44,45], etc. The titanium oxide can generate stronger interaction with the noble metal catalyst (Pt, Ir, Ru, etc.) compared with traditional carbon supports [46–50]. Meanwhile, the electronic configuration of the metal catalyst can be tuned when interacting with the support [51], which tend to result in excellent catalytic performance and stability. In this review, the recent advances of titanium oxide-based support in electrochemical reactions are summarized in detail. This review starts with understanding the metal-support interaction and classification of different kinds of titanium oxide-based support materials, then thoroughly discusses the design of the catalyst and focuses on the support effects on the catalytic performance. We hope this article can update and summarize the designing strategy of the supported catalysts and provide possible suggestions or advices for future catalysts design. 2 Metal-support interaction Understanding the metal-support interaction is crucial for designing highly active and stable electrocatalysts. Other than enhancing the dispersion of nanoparticles, the support effect also exhibits a significant role in tuning the reactivity of metal catalysts [52]. The metal-support interactions involve multiple aspects as shown in Fig. 1 (a), including the charge transfer, interfacial perimeter, nanoparticle morphology, chemical composition and strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) [53]. In a narrow sense, the SMSI means the metal nanoparticles with suboxides coverage on the surface, indicating a broader contact between nanoparticles and supports. For example, the formation of a thin film of reduced titania on Pt surface is selective permeability for H transport while the oxygenated species are limited, which contributes to the ability to oxidize hydrogen even above 1.0 V. While this SMSI led to the decreased activity in ORR, OER and CO oxidation reaction [54]. In a general sense, SMSI refers to a prominent influence of inert support on the catalytic activity of metal nanoparticles. The influence of support on metal nanoparticles in SMSI includes the electronic effect, dispersing effect and geometric effect (Fig. 1b) [55]. In this review, the so-called SMSI in the later sections means that in the general sense. Commonly, a strong metal-support interaction generated as the metal particle size decreased [56,57]. The nanoparticle size also influences the chemical potential of metals [58], which could contribute to an inverse charge transfer between the interface of metal nanoparticle and support. Meanwhile, the stabilizing effect of support mainly protects nanoparticles from sintering or ripening. On the other hand, overstrong metal-support interaction would lead to the performance degradation. For example, the CeO2 supported Ru single atoms with a higher SMSI display a deceased activity for low-temperature CO2 methanation compared with the CeO2 supported Ru clusters (Fig. 1c) [59]. Besides, the morphology of supports also plays a significant role in influencing the sintering rate of nanoparticles [60]. For the oxides supports, the generation of O vacancies in the metal-support interface further tuned the catalytic performance relative to the common oxides [61]. To conclude, strengthening the metal-support interactions by tuning the component, morphology and surface defect of support could promote both the activity and stability of metal catalysts. 3 Different types of TiO x -based supports 3.1 Shaped TiO2 A further treatment on the stoichiometric TiO2 support is usually employed to improve the electrocatalytic performance. Morphology tuning is an effective strategy to acquire large specific area, which provided more active sites for metal catalyst and also favored the mass transfer process. Preparing one-dimensional TiO2 nanotubes, two-dimensional TiO2 nanosheets or films and three-dimensional TiO2 with unique morphologies offers a higher specific surface area and more porosities, enabling their applications as electrocatalysts supports. Many methods have been employed to prepare one-dimensional TiO2 nanotubes to promote the dispersion of nanoparticles. Assaud and co-authors [62] prepared TiO2 nanotubes firstly via an anodic oxidation method and then Pd nanoparticles were loaded onto the TiO2 nanotubes by atomic layer deposition method (Fig. 2 a). Compared with the as-grown TiO2 nanotubes, the annealed TiO2 nanotubes exhibited a higher promoting effect in ethanol oxidation reaction due to the improved conductivity and metal-support interaction. However, Lei and co-authors [63] found Pt nanoparticles is difficult to be loaded onto TiO2 nanotubes on a Ti substrate. To facilitate the dispersion of Pt and limit its aggregation, TiO2 nanotubes supported Pt-Pd binary were prepared with improved dispersion of Pt-Pd nanoparticles relative to Pt (Fig. 2b and c), which contributed to a higher catalytic activity and poisoning tolerance in methanol oxidation reaction compared with monometallic catalyst. Further combined with photo-catalysis, the electrocatalytic activity toward methanol oxidation reaction was increased. He et al. [64] prepared Pt-Ni nanoparticles dispersed on the TiO2 nanotube arrays via a pulse electrodeposition method. The reaction rate of TiO2 nanotube supported PtNi nanoparticles for MOR with light has been promoted obviously compared with the value for MOR under dark. Two-dimensional TiO2 nanosheets or films display a huge potential as catalyst support for membrane electrode-assembly and gas diffusion electrode. Gustavsson and co-authors [66] found that a TiO2 thin film layer between Pt and Nafion could improve ORR performance compared with Pt directly deposited on Nafion, which is resulted by the promoted dispersion of Pt and proton conductivity. When employed in gas diffusion electrode setup, porous Ti nanosheets were etched by NaOH to generate the TiO2 nanostructures on the surface [65]. Then Ir nanoparticles were deposited on the support via an arc plasma deposition method (Fig. 2d). By controlling the number of arc plasma deposition pulses, a higher electrocatalytic performance towards water electrolysis was achieved with a lower Ir loading. Three-dimensional urchin-like mesoporous TiO2 hollow spheres (UMTHS) were fabricated via a hydrothermal method and uniform Pt NPs were loaded on the surface as shown in Fig. 3 (a) [67]. This special structure of TiO2 exhibited large specific surface area of 167.1 m2 g−1, which favored the charge transfer process. The Pt/UMTHS catalysts showed enhanced ORR activity than commercial Pt/C catalyst and superior cycling performance with a lower mass activity (MA) loss rate after long term stability tests, which could be attributed to the restricted ripening of Pt nanoparticles on UMTHS support (Fig. 3b). Different from regular supporting strategy, Wei and co-authors [68] proposed a novel idea that Ru clusters were partially confined in the lattice of TiO2 (Fig. 3c). The urchin-like Ru@TiO2 catalysts exhibited remarkable HOR activity under both alkaline and acid conditions, which was ascribed to that the electron transfer effect altered the electronic structure of Ru and subsequently influenced the adsorption of surface species. Moreover, the HOR activity remained a high value in 1,000 ppm CO impurity and even 10 vol% CO, proving a high CO-tolerance of Ru@TiO2 catalysts. The HRTEM image in Fig. 3(d) confirmed the confining effect of Ru, where a new crystal structure appeared between the crystalline TiO2 and Ru. Non-Pt group metals are also investigated for shaped TiO2 support [69]. A tube-in-tube structured MnO2@TiO2 hybrid arrays [70] were prepared through chemical bath deposition method, the current density of the MnO2@TiO2 hybrid catalyst was 97 times higher than pristine TiO2 nanotube arrays. Wu and Zelenay [71] reported TiO2 supported non-precious metal catalyst for ORR and only 20 mV gap in half-wave potential was observed between PANI-Fe-TiO2 and Pt/C catalyst. Polyaniline precursor was in situ polymerized onto the surface of TiO2 with Fe precursor species along. The resultant PANI-Fe-TiO2 catalyst showed excellent ORR activity in both rotating disk electrode (RDE) and fuel cell polarization curves, with little difference with Pt/C catalyst. In summary, varies shaped TiO2 are proven to be promising candidates as supports for various catalysts including but not limited to noble metal. These TiO2 supports features higher specific surface area and porosity, which is beneficial for dispersing of nanoparticles and promoting mass transfer. Most of these TiO2 supports are composed by the anatase crystal phase. Assisted by light, the electrocatalytic performance could be further improved. However, the electronic conductivity is still limited compared with the other TiO x with oxygen vacancy or doped by heteroatoms. 3.2 Doped TiO2 Heteroatoms doping is an effective method to enhance the conductivity of TiO2 [72]. Usually, the dopant metal atom can be introduced into the lattice of TiO2 and existed in the form of oxide. As a result, Mo [73–77], W [78], Nb [72,79–81] and Ru [82–85] are the most common doping elements because their oxide show better conductivity than common oxides. In a typical synthesis of doped TiO2, titanium precursor and dopant metal precursor are simultaneously added into solvent and go through hydrolysis reaction under sol–gel or solvothermal reaction. 3.2.1 Metal doped TiO2 An oriented attachment mechanism was reported by Huang and co-authors [84] to fabricate a Ru-doped TiO2 catalyst with Ru-doped SrTi1− x Ru x O3 as precursor. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), bulk SrTiO3 was firstly corroded into the monodispersed TiO2 nanoparticles (Fig. 4b). After an oriented attachment process, mesoporous crystal TiO2 was obtained (Fig. 4c). When the SrTiO3 was doped with Ru, Ru doped TiO2 with different Ru content was obtained. As shown in the LSV curves in Fig. 4(d), R-TiO2: Ru (5%) showed the best HER activity in 0.1 M KOH, with a 150 mV overpotential at 10 mA cm−2, only 41 mV higher than that of Pt/C. And Ru doped TiO2 supported Pt (Pt/Ti0.7Ru0.3O2) also exhibited improving performance in the direct methanol fuel cell [83]. Mo-doped TiO2 also displayed a significant role in promoting electrocatalytic performance. In Fig. 4(e), Mo doping and carbon coating were achieved simultaneously to support PtRu nanoparticles (PtRu/C@MTNC-FI) [77]. This core–shell support featured an abundant Mo-functionalized interface contained by ultrafine grain-sized crystalline core and graphitized carbon-coated shell (Fig. 4f). Electron donation from Mo-functionalized interface to PtRu nanoparticles contributed to the strong SMSI and anchoring effect. Thus, PtRu/C@MTNC-FI showed greatly enhanced activity and stability toward methanol oxidation reaction. Ti0.9Mo0.1O2 supported low-Pt electrocatalyst was reported with highly durable HER performance [86]. 5 wt% loading of Pt was deposited on the spherical Ti0.9Mo0.1O2 support, the catalysts showed improved HER activity than 20 wt% Pt/C catalysts with comparable overpotential at 10 mA cm−2. Moreover, the mass activity of Pt/Ti0.9Mo0.1O2 at 50 mV overpotential was 4.4 times as much as Pt/C. Enhanced durability was revealed with ADT test, only 7.8 % mass activity loss was observed for Pt/Ti0.9Mo0.1O2, pronouncedly superior to 33.8 % loss for Pt/C catalyst. Hwang’s group reported a series of works in doped TiO2 supported catalysts for ORR [74–76,87]. The nanostructured Pt/Ti0.7Mo0.3O2 catalyst with only 3–4 nm size exhibited enhanced activity and stability towards ORR. The synchrotron radiation technique was commonly used in their work to characterize the electronic configuration of Pt. Doping W element into TiO2 requires special attention on the valence of W. To ensure W element existed as conductive WO2 state instead of semiconductor WO3, a sol–gel method followed by a Zr foil reduction strategy was used in Abruña’s group in 2010 [78]. The Ti0.7W0.3O2 supported Pt catalyst exhibited excellent HOR activity and high CO-tolerance. Differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) measurements revealed that the onset potential for CO oxidation was below 0.1 V, proving that CO tended to be oxidized at the relatively low potential for Pt/Ti0.7W0.3O2 catalyst. Park et al. [80] found that the Nb-doped TiO2 supported Pt catalyst showed better activity than carbon-supported ones and analyzed the results with electron microscopy and X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra. The Pt/Nb-TiO2 exhibited smaller Pt nanoparticle size and well dispersion, and the SMSI may contribute to the excellent ORR activity. In the following years, several works proved the stability of Nb-doped TiO2 supported catalysts. In addition, the Pt/Nb-doped TiO2 [79] and PdAg/Nb x Ti1- x O2 [88] also exhibited superior stability in ORR and EOR, respectively. Nb-doped TiO2 nanotubes (Nb-TNTs) were also applied to support IrO2 and IrRuO x NPs for oxygen evolution reaction [72]. The operating conditions in OER are highly corrosive, so it pose great challenge for the catalyst and its support. The Nb-TNTs offer great corrosion resistance and stability in high potential range. Besides, it possesses large surface area owing to its unique 2D structure. According to the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis, the Nb species mainly existed as Nb (IV) oxide, which was suitable to introduce free electrons to the conduction band of TiO2 and thus improved its electronic conductivity. Nb doped TiO2 supported catalyst also have promoted ethanol oxidation reaction. Other than above mentioned elements, Ta and Co have also been doped into TiO2 support to promote the electrocatalytic performance. Zhang et al. [89] prepared tantalum (Ta) doped TiO2 NPs also via a sol–gel method. The incorporation of oxygen vacancies and Ta doping into the TiO2 crystal lattice improved the electronic conductivity of TiO2. After the accelerated durability test for ORR, the attenuation of the electrochemical active surface area of Pt/Ta-TiO2 was smaller than that of Pt supported on carbon black, demonstrating better stability was achieved with Ta doped TiO2 support. The Ta dope TiO2 supports also promoted the fuel cell performance of Pt. Kumar and Ramani prepared Rutile Ta0.3Ti0.7O2 supported Pt and SMSI was revealed by the XANES results. After accelerated stability tests for 10, 000 cycles, the voltage loss at 0.4 mA cm−2 was only 23 mV on 20% Pt/Ta0.3Ti0.7O2, which is only one-tenth of that on Pt/C, demonstrating the superior stability of 20% Pt/Ta0.3Ti0.7O2 [90]. Tian and Yang et al. [91] reported for the first time one-dimensional Co doped TiO2 nanotubes constructed by ultrathin nanosheets assembles applied as supports for Pt NPs. The ORR activity of the Pt/Ti1- x Co x O2 increased when the value of x increased from 0 to 0.2. When x = 0.25, the activity degraded badly due to the severe structure collapse of the nanotubes. The mass activity at 0.9 V for Pt/Ti0.2Co0.8O2 was 0.53 A mg-1 Pt, which was 2.7 times higher than Pt/C. The Ti1- x Co x O2 support served as a co-catalyst by modulate the electronic structure of the Pt catalyst, thus achieving excellent performance. 3.2.2 Non-metal doped TiO2 Recently, N,C-codoped Ti3+-enriched TiO2 supported Pt catalyst was reported by Tak et al. [92] with highly durable PEMFC performance. Oxygen vacancies were introduced through solid-state mixing of TiO2 and urea followed by high temperature annealing as probed by electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR). The Pt/N,C-codoped TiO2 exhibited superior durability with only 7 % electrochemical surface area (ECSA) decrease after 10,000 ADT cycles, while Pt/C suffered from 40 % loss. Moreover, the mass activity of Pt/N,C-codoped TiO2 even increased after ADT when that of Pt/C was significantly lost by 54 %. Similar improvement in stability can also be seen in single cell test. After 5,000 cycles between 1.0–1.5 V, the maximum power density of Pt/C decreased by 52 % and only by 4 % for Pt/N,C-codoped TiO2. The N doping into TiO2 nanotubes to form TiON also induced SMSI, which reduced the aggregation tendency of Ir nanoparticles according to Bele’s density functional theory (DFT) calculation results. XPS and EPR analyses revealed the existence of Ti3+ and oxygen vacancies, which resulted in a pronounced SMSI effect and therefore the catalysts showed excellent stability. Benefited by the protective oxides, TiON-Ir showed excellent OER performance [93]. Hwang also reported cation and anion co-doping of TiO2 at the same time [87]. The Pt/Ti0.8W0.2N x O y catalyst showed 3.7 times more active performance than Pt/Ti0.8W0.2Oy without nitrogen doping. The dual doping strategy provided stronger electron transfer from the support to Pt, resulting from the SMSI. DFT calculations proved the Pt/Ti0.8W0.2Oy showed superior activity because the dual-doped TiO2 possessed more defects. The doped TiO2 displayed higher proportion of Ti3+, which is beneficial for improving the electronic conductivity. Most of the doped TiO2 supports are composed by the anatase crystal phase and SMSI were induced. Table 1 summarized recent doped TiO2 supported Pt catalysts for ORR activity and durability. The doped TiO2 supported catalysts have shown superior stability compared with the carbon supported catalysts. However, the electrocatalytic activity towards these electrochemical reactions needs to be further promoted. 3.3 Titanium suboxide We have described that Magnéli phase titanium oxides exhibit significant electronic conductivity relative to those phases with stoichiometric TiO2. Thus, Magnéli phase titanium oxides have been widely employed as the supports. To elevate the conductivity of TiO2, hydrogen or high temperature treatment can be conducted. Although the crystal structure of TiO2 always remains unchanged after the treatment, oxygen vacancies were introduced into the support during the calcination process [94,95] and were usually proved by electron spin resonance (ESR), EPR, XPS, Raman spectra and DFT results [96,97]. These TiO2- x crystals with oxygen vacancies are different from the titanium suboxides. SMSI was introduced through high temperature reduction procedure [98,99], and reasonable tuning of the metal-support interactions can further improve the activity and stability of TiO2- x supported catalysts. 3.3.1 TixO2x-1 supported Pt-based catalysts Recently, titanium suboxides supports have aroused wide attention in electrocatalysis [100-104]. Zhang and co-workers [105] reported Ti4O7 supported Pt applied in ORR. The electrospinning method was used to synthesize the TiO2 nanofibers, which were then calcined at 550 °C for 3 h in the air followed by H2 reduction at 1050 °C for 6 h to be transformed into Ti4O7. The Ti4O7 support processed both good thermal and chemical stability. However, the mass activity of Pt/Ti4O7 catalyst degraded drastically due to the formation of the insulating TiO2 layer on the catalyst surface. The high temperature treat inevitably decreased the specific area of Ti4O7 while increased the conductivity. However, Hwang and co-workers [41] used the silica shell as a template to confine the Ti4O7 particle (Fig. 5 a) and avoid specific area decreases. Besides, the optimum catalyst showed enhanced stability with only 66 % mass activity decay while Pt/C suffered from 85 % loss (Fig. 5b). R. A. M. Esfahani [106] and co-workers reported Pt/Ti3O5-Mo catalyst for stable ORR. The integration of Mo co-catalyst and Pt catalyst achieved better ORR performance. The mass activity achieved 73.3 mA mg−1, nearly double that of commercial Pt/C. On this basis, this group added silica element and fabricated Ti3O5Mo0.2Si0.4 (TOMS) supported Pt catalyst (Fig. 5c) [107], which showed extraordinary durability with only 10 % ECSA loss after 5,000 accelerated stress test cycles and minimal change after the fuel cell performance test (Fig. 5d). A bifunctional PtIr/Ti4O7 catalysts were reported with enhanced ORR and OER activity (Fig. 5e) [108]. The HRTEM images in Fig. 5(f) confirmed the successful synthesis of PtIr particles on Ti4O7 support. The PtIr/Ti4O7 catalyst showed both excellent ORR activity (Fig. 5g) and OER activity. 3.3.2 TixO2x-1 supported non Pt-based catalysts A Ti4O7 supported three-dimensional flower-like NiRu layered double hydroxide (3D-FL-NiRu-LDH/Ti4O7) was prepared with an in-situ growth method (Fig. 6 a) [101]. The ORR activity of 3D-FL-NiRu-LDH/Ti4O7 was significantly enhanced and outperformed recently reported LDH catalysts in alkaline solution (Fig. 6b). Galyamova and co-authors [109] investigated the support effect on the ORR performance of Au nanoparticles (Fig. 6c). The direct contact of Au nanoparticles with TiO x substrate was prevented when the Au nanoparticles were encapsulated by poly(amidoamine) dendrimers (G6-NH2), which (PPF/TiO1.9(60)/G6-NH2(Au147)) showed a poor ORR activity. After removing the dendrimers, PPF/TiO1.9(60)/Au147 showed enhanced ORR performance. TiO2 supported Au nanoparticles also showed improved ORR activity compared with the unsupported ones, demonstrating the promoting effect of TiO x substrate. The titanium suboxide (TiO1.9) support exhibited a better promotion relative TiO2 support, which is attributed to the charge transfer from oxygen vacancies at the interface of Au nanoparticle and TiO1.9 support and formation of active anionic Au species. Qi and co-authors [102] reported Ti4O7 supported NiCoP/CoP catalysts. The NiCoP/CoP might receive electron from Ti4O7 and increase the content of Ni2+, which could accelerate the HER process [110]. The NiCoP/CoP-Ti4O7 exhibited an overpotential of 128 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and negligible performance degradation after 1,000 CV cycles. MoS2 was a promising catalyst for HER catalyst. However, low conductivity of MoS2 materials severely hinders the charge transfer during the HER reaction. Zhao and co-authors [104] reported a facile synthesis of molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) and conducting Magnéli phase Ti4O7 composite (Fig. 6d) via a hydrothermal method. The resultant MoS2/Ti4O7 catalyst showed significantly improved HER activity with a 287 mV overpotential at 10 mA cm−2. After 1,000 potential cycles, only a 5 mV potential shift was observed, demonstrating excellent stability, which was attributed to the electron transferred from Ti4O7 to MoS2 facilitated by interfacial S-O-Ti bonds. 3.3.3 TiO2-x with oxygen vacancies The generation of oxygen vacancies also led to the enhanced electronic conductivity relative to the pristine TiO2 supports and induced SMSI to influence electrocatalytic performance of metal catalysts. Stühmeier and co-authors [111] reported Pt/TiO x /C400 ℃, H 2 catalyst for highly selective HOR reaction. The as-prepared Pt/TiO x /C was treated with 5% H2/Ar to form a TiO x layer on the surface of Pt, serving as a selective tunnel for reactant. The existence of oxide layer was verified with HRTEM images. It was reported that the TiO x layer was permselective for protons instead of hydroxyl groups. Therefore, the ORR activity of Pt/TiO x /C400 ℃, H 2 was severely suppressed compared with commercial Pt/C catalyst, the high HOR activity was remained even at high potentials up to 1.4 V (vs. RHE). However, in the reduction process, TiO2 may be reduced to some extent and cover the active sites, resulting in performance degradation. To solve this issue, an effective hydrofluoric acid (HF) etching approach was reported by Hwang and co-authors [112] to alleviate the interaction and recover the performance of high temperature treated Pt/TiO2-HT. The reduced TiO2- x layer covered on the Pt NPs prevented the OHad approaching the active Pt sites, hindering the ORR process. The oxide layer can be verified via high-resolution transmission microscope (HRTEM) and XPS. After HF treatment, the layer can be effectively etched away, restoring the ability to access OHad and therefore regain the ORR activity as that of the Pt/TiO2, which can be observed in the cyclic voltammetry (CV) changes. As shown in Fig. 7 (a), oxygen vacancies-rich and oxygen vacancies-deficient TiO2 can be obtained by choosing the H2PtCl6 and K2PtCl4 as the precursor [8], respectively. Abundant oxygen vacancies can realize the reversed charge transfer with electrons transferring from TiO2 to Pt. In the meantime, the hydrogen spillover effect was simultaneously enhanced, accelerating the hydrogen desorption. The facile pyrolysis method was applied to prepare Pd nanoparticles supported on TiO2 with abundant oxygen vacancies (Pd/TiO2-VO) [26] as seen in Fig. 7(b). ESR and XPS characterization demonstrated the successful introduction of abundant oxygen vacancies, and the charge transfer from TiO2-VO to Pd was verified by density functional theory calculations. The adsorption energy of OOH over Pd/TiO2-VO was lower than other structures, exhibiting enhanced adsorption capacity of the intermediates. NaBH4 reduction method was also applied to produce oxygen deficient TiO2 support (TiO2- x ) for Pt [113]. The as-prepared TiO2 nanosheets were treated with 10 mol L-1 NaBH4 solution. Oxygen vacancies were proved by the positive shift to a higher value in Raman spectra. The XPS results also demonstrate oxygen vacancies by the change in O 1 s peak of Pt-TiO2- x . In addition, Pt 4f core level spectra of Pt-TiO2- x shifted to lower binding energy, which indicates d-band center shifted relative to Fermi level, reducing the adsorption of the intermediates on the catalyst surface and then improve ORR performance. Green synthesis of TiO2 nanorods was reported by Krishnan and co-authors [114] and NaBH4 was used to reduce Pt and generate oxygen vacancies (Fig. 7c). The absorption in infrared region in UV–vis absorption spectra and weak peaks at 388, 423, and 450 nm in photoluminescence (PL) spectra were attributed to oxygen vacancies. The similarities and differences of promoting effect in TiO2- x support with oxygen vacancies and titanium suboxide support are compared for an accurate knowledge. The similarities including the improved electronic conductivity, induced SMSI and resulted enhanced electrocatalytic performances. The differences mainly lie in the crystal phase and morphologies. The titanium suboxide mainly composed by the Magnéli phase with spherical shape. TiO2- x supports with oxygen vacancies are mainly composed by the rutile and anatase phase with tunable morphologies like rod, sheets et al. and porosity. These TiO x displayed higher proportion of oxygen vacancies, leading to their superior electronic conductivity. The oxygen vacancies also induced SMSI and then promote the electrocatalytic performances in varies electrochemical reactions. However, formation of Magnéli phase at higher temperatures is energy consuming and they tend to be oxidized into TiO2 during long term operating. Other than creating the oxygen vacancies, promoting the electrocatalytic activity of metal catalysts combined with the alloying strategy is expected. 3.4 TiO2-carbon composites Compositing with conductive carbon materials is another effective way to improve the conductivity of TiO2 [10,115–119]. The oxide–carbon composites combine the advantage of carbon and TiO2 and show both excellent electronic conductivity and corrosion resistance [120]. The carbon in the composite was found to be transformed into a highly graphitized carbon allotrope and showed better corrosion resistance than pure carbon [121]. Carbon black (Vulcan XC-72), carbon nanotube (CNT) and carbon nanofibers (CNF) were commonly investigated to composite with TiO2 [117,122–125]. In another case, when stoichiometric TiO2 is used as the support, the appropriate amount of conductive carbon such as carbon black are required to be mixed with TiO2 supported catalysts before being loaded onto the electrode to ensure the electron transfer process. Behm et al. [126] have studied the effect of support in Pt catalyst degradation under fuel starvation, it turned out that physical mixture of TiO2 and conductive carbon can prevent the dissolution of catalyst particle as a sacrificial species. Combining the merits of conductive carbon and stable oxide, the resultant support can favor excellent catalytic performance. 3.4.1 TiO2 composited with CNT/CNF A nanofibrous TiO2-CNF composite with a 3D structure [121] was prepared as shown in Fig. 8 (a), which improves the mass-transfer property of the catalyst. The XANES results revealed a downshift of the d-band vacancy of Pt as a result of electron transfer from the CNF/TiO2 support induced by the SMSI effect. The catalyst exhibited excellent ORR activity. Moreover, during high potential cycling between 1.0–1.6 V, the CNF/TiO2-Pt showed much better stability with only 4% ECSA loss while 74% for Pt/C, which can be attributed to the corrosion resistance of TiO2 in high potential range. Park and co-authors [123] reported carbon nanotube-winded Pt/TiO2 nanofibers (Fig. 8b). The addition of CNT provided a sufficient charge transfer pathway and the XPS and X-ray absorption spectroscopy analyses revealed the electronic configuration of Pt was changed possibly due to the SMSI between the Pt and CNF-TiO2. As a consequence, the CNT-Pt/TiO2 showed superior membrane electrode assembly performance at 120 ℃ and relative humidity of 40 % than commercial Pt/C. The ultrathin TiO2 film coating on multiwalled carbon nanotube (MWCNT@UT-TiO2) prepared by a sol–gel method also displayed a significant role in promoting the ORR performance of Pt. The electron transfer from support to Pt, promoted the ORR performance resulted by the SMSI. Besides, the Pt-MWCNT@UT-TiO2 delivered enhanced durability compared with carbon supported Pt catalysts [127]. Similar results were also found in MWCNTs@TiO2–TiC supported Pt catalyst [128]. Wang et al. [129] synthesized TiO2-C composites using a liquid-phase assembly process (Fig. 8c). The high conductive Vulcan XC-72 was mixed with TiO2 to form conductive support, then a photochemical deposition process was used to load Pt onto the TiO2-C support. Electron transfer was facilitated due to the SMSI. As a result, such catalyst showed excellent ORR activity and stability in an acidic medium and high-temperature environment. Besides, the half-wave potential of Pt/TiO2-C showed a 49 mV positive shift than the commercial 20% Pt/C catalyst. 3.4.2 TiO2-carbon composites with structured morphologies Pt NPs were supported on carbon-coated TiO2-reduced graphene oxide (rGO) hollow nanosphere [120] following the procedure in Fig. 9 (a). The Pt/rGO/TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 9b) displayed outstanding cycling stability under high potential cycling between 1.2–1.7 V. And Pt/rGO/TiO2 showed excellent activity in ORR with comparable activity and less ECSA loss. Moreover, negligible voltage drop was seen over during fuel cell test as shown in Fig. 9(c). Gao et al. [118] developed template-oriented strategy to fabricate double-shelled C/TiO2 (DSCT) hollow spheres to support ultrafine Pt NPs (Fig. 9d). The shell structure with a diameter about 500 nm was clearly observed by TEM in Fig. 9(e). The methanol oxidation test results in Fig. 9(f) showed that the current density of Pt/DSCT was 2.52 times higher than commercial Pt/C catalyst. Lou et al. [125] designed a sandwich-structured TiO2-Pt-graphene composite catalyst. The graphene provides high conductivity for the catalyst and also the metal-support interaction with the hybrids. The ternary catalysts exhibited improved methanol oxidation activity compared with the conventional Pt/C catalyst, which can be ascribed to the unique sandwich-like configuration and possible synergetic effect between the hybrids. 3.4.3 TiO2 physically mixed with conductive carbon In 2009, a controllable method to load ultrafine noble metal particles on TiO2 was presented by Liu and co-authors [130]. In this work, titanium (III) dioxide nanostructure was prepared with TiCl3 hydrolyzing in acidic solution, and the metal ions were reduced and the formed nanoparticles were uniformly dispersed on the support as shown in Fig. 10 (a and b). On this basis, Zhang et al. [131] prepared TiO2 supported Pt clusters catalyst with similar method. The active sites come from the highly oxidized Pt clusters (Fig. 10c), which can be confirmed by the XANES data. The TiO2 supported Pt clusters remained almost unchanged after the accelerated durability test (ADT) in Fig. 10(d) with similar size distribution relative to that before ADT during the hydrogen evolution reaction, in contrast to that the carbon supported nanoparticles (NPs) easily aggregate into large ones. The excellent durability for HER (Fig. 10e) was probably caused by the strong interaction between the PtO x and TiO2. Other than TiO2 supported noble metal catalysts, single-site Co atoms were introduced into brookite Co-TiO2 nanorods (Fig. 10f), which showed excellent OER activity [132]. The nanorods existed in the form of single crystals and grow along the < 001 > direction as shown in Fig. 10(g). The OER activity of Co-TiO2 was significantly improved compared with IrO2 and CoO particles (Fig. 10h). In summary, compositing conductive carbon and corrosion-resistant TiO2 serves as ideal support for noble metal catalysts. In addition, the versatile morphologies of oxide–carbon composite enlarge the surface area, providing more active sites to anchor the catalysts particles. The TiO x are composed by the brookite or anatase mostly. Both the chemically and physically mixed composites show improved electronic conductivity and enhanced electrocatalytic activity. The stability performance of TiO2-carbon supported catalysts is prominently enhanced in consideration of the merit of this composite. For the chemically mixed TiO x -C composites, templates are usually employed, indicating a tedious preparation process. While for the physically mixed TiO x -C composites, the uniform contact is difficult to control and the ratio of TiO x and C needs to be further optimized. 4 Roles of titanium oxide support In this section, the detailed mechanisms of the role of TiO x -based supports are discussed. For all the electrochemical reaction, the TiO x supports not only stabilize and promote the dispersion of metal nanoparticles, but also tune the electronic structure of metal catalysts via interfacial charge transfer. The doping of heteroatoms or generating O vacancy could further influence the electronic structure of metal catalysts and simultaneously promote the electronic conductivity of TiO x supports. By controlling the morphology of TiO x supports, the aggregation of nanoparticles is suppressed due to confining effect as a physical barrier as well as SMSI. Besides, the increased porosity could facilitate the mass transfer process. TiO x support also serves as a cocatalyst in certain electrochemical reactions (Fig. 11 ). The enhanced H spillover effect on TiO x accelerate the HER process. During the HOR, the selective permeability of H2 rather than O or OH allows the HOR happens even at a higher potential. For other reactions like OER, ORR and MOR, the significant electron transfer caused by SMSI displays a major role in promoting electrocatalytic activity. In addition, the doped heteroatoms are active in some electrocatalytic reactions and contribute to the catalytic performance. 5 Conclusions and perspectives In this review, TiO x -based support used in common electrocatalytic systems has been summarized and discussed. Utilizing the chemical stability of TiO x , the TiO x -based materials supported catalysts show superior durability and activity than carbon supported catalysts. To overcome the intrinsic drawback of low conductivity of TiO2, tremendous efforts have been made to engineering TiO x structure, including generating oxygen vacancy, doping with heteroatoms, forming titanium suboxide and compositing with carbon. All the aforementioned methods are aimed at enhancing the electronic conductivity of TiO x to ensure charge transfer efficiency in the electrochemical catalytic reactions. Among these strategies, oxygen vacancies are usually generated through reduction treatment of pure TiO2, for instance, hydrogen reduction or NaBH4 reduction. Through the reduction process, the Ti4+ is partially reduced to Ti3+ and oxygen vacancies are produced simultaneously. When hydrogen reduction temperature rises up to 1,000 ℃, titanium suboxide (Ti x O2 x -1) with high conductivity can be produced. In the meantime, various metal or non-metal elements can be introduced to dope TiO2 to improve the conductivity. In addition, combining conductive carbon materials with TiO2 also pave a way for stable support, with carbon ensuring the charge transfer process and TiO2 ensuring the stability of the composite support. In most cases, the TiO x -based support can generate strong metal-support interaction with the supported metal catalysts and therefore charge transfer is induced from the TiO x to supported metal (Pt, Pd, etc.), changing the electron density of metal and tuning the binding energy with the intermediate, thus enhancing the catalytic activity. Therefore, reasonably tuning the metal to support interaction plays a significant part in improving the catalytic performance. Despite the progress have made by engineering TiO x -based support, challenges are still present in current research. (1) It is admitted that TiO x supported nanocatalysts showed superior stability than the carbon supported ones, but the electrocatalytic activity is required to be further promoted. For example, the state-of-the-art Pt-based nanocatalysts have shown an order of magnitude improvement in ORR activity compared with Pt/C, which is less achieved on TiO x supported Pt-based catalysts. (2) The sub-stoichiometric titanium oxides tend to be oxidized into the stoichiometric TiO2, which would lead to decreased electronic conductivity and electrocatalytic performance. (3) Compared with nanoparticles, the TiO x supported single atoms and fully exposed clusters are less concerned. As displayed in Fig. 12 , we would like to recommend the following strategy for designing oxide supported catalyst for electrocatalysis reaction: (1) Preparing heteroatoms dope TiO x supported polymetallic alloy catalysts. Utilizing the electronic effect induced by alloying to promote the electrocatalytic activity, accompanied by the charge transfer between the TiO x supports and catalysts. During the preparing process, the alloyed elements are expected to be doped into TiO x supports to promote the electronic conductivity synchronously. (2) Developing the electrochemical method to create oxygen vacancies. Electrochemically generating oxygen vacancies is beneficial to promote the electronic conductivity of stoichiometric TiO2 and reuse the sub-stoichiometric titanium oxides after long term cycling. (3) Developing novel strategies to achieve a uniform dispersion of metal catalysts, including chemical reduction, electrochemical deposition, and photochemical reduction and so on. The catalyst loading on TiO x support should be reduced to realize higher mass activity by developing fully exposed nanocluster or single atom catalysts. Moreover, versatile catalysts beyond noble metal should be explored to be supported on TiO x materials to realize considerable activity. TiO x supported transition metal oxide, sulfide and carbide are considered to be promising candidate with both high activity, excellent stability and low cost. (4) Amplifying the interfacial effect via decorating the self-supported catalysts with TiO x . The self-supported catalysts have shown higher porosity, specific surface area and structural stability. Further decorating the surface with TiO x or other species to amplifying the interfacial effect, the electrocatalytic performance are expected to be further optimized. Zhang, Nat. Catal. 4 (2020) 36-45. Ke Chen received his M.S. under the supervision of Prof. Deli Wang at School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology. He received his B.S. degree in chemicalengineeringandtechnology from Huazhong University of Science and Technology in 2018. His current research is focused on the design and application of TiO2-based materials as robust catalyst support for electrocatalytical reactions. Tao Shen is a Ph.D. candidate in Huazhong University of Science and Technology (HUST) under the supervision of Prof. Deli Wang. He received his bachelor’s degree in Northwest Agriculture & Forestry University (NWAFU) in 2017. His research interests focus on the design of highly effective nanocatalysts for direct liquid fuel cells (DLFC) on both the anode and cathode. Yun Lu receivedhis Ph.D. underthesupervisionofProf.DeliWangat Huazhong University of Science & Technology (HUST). He received his M.S. in the School of Materials Science and Engineering, Hubei University, in 2018. His research interests focus on the design and synthesis functional polymers or ramification for high performance energy storage electrode material. Yezhou Hu received his M.S. under the supervision of Prof. Deli Wang at School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology. His research mainly focus on the design and synthesis of Pd-based nanomaterials and its application in proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs). Jingyu Wang is a professor at the School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology. Prior to that, she worked as an associate professor at Harbin Institute of Technology and a visiting scholar at the University of Chicago. She received her Ph.D. degree in chemistry from Wuhan University in 2007. Her current research interest includes the development of photocatalysts for environmental and energy applications. Dr. Jian Zhang is currently working as an associate professor at School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology (HUST). He received his PhD from Wuhan University of Technology in 2015. Afterwards, he joined HUST, Nanyang Technological University and Singapore University of Science and Design as research fellow (2015–2019), respectively. His research is mainly focused on electrocatalysis and electrosynthesis, including water splitting, fuel cell and metal-air batteries, H2O2 production, wastewater treatment, and the related devices. Deli Wang received her Ph.D. from Wuhan University in 2008. And then she joined in Nanyang Technological University working as a research fellow for one year. She moved to Cornell University in 2009, joined in Energy Materials Center at Cornell (EMC2) as a postdoctoral associate for three years. In the end of 2012, she came back to China. She is currently a professor of School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huazhong University of Science & Technology (HUST). Her research interests mainly focused on nanomaterials for energy conversion and storage.

coredata.dc:description: The corrosion and weaker interaction with metal catalysts of common carbon supports during electrocatalysis push the development of alternative supports materials. Titanium oxide-based materials have been widely explored as electrocatalysts supports in consideration of their chemical stability, strong interactions with metal catalyst and wider applications in electrocatalytic reactions as well as the improved electronic conductivity. This review summarizes recent research advances in engineering titanium oxide-based supports for the catalysts in electrocatalysis field to provide guidance for designing high performance non-carbon supported electrocatalysts. Typically, the titanium oxide-based supports are classified into shaped TiO2, doped TiO2, titanium suboxide and TiO2-carbon composites according to the modification methods and corresponding preparation methods. Then the engineering strategies and electrocatalytic applications are discussed in detail. Finally, the challenges, future research directions and perspectives of titanium oxide-based supports for electrocatalysis are presented for practical applications.
